prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: n6240
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For NGC 6240, the observed CO(2-1) flux is 4.1 Jy (Greve et al. 2009) Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 10.2 mJy and 3.4 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a singal-to-noise ratio of about 13 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 4.5 H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 1.5 beams. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 5.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 2.4 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 3.
We set a LAS size of 4.2 arcsec, correponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.
All basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: f18293
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For IRAS F18293-3413, the observed CO(2-1) flux is 4.1 Jy (Aalto et al. 1995). Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 10.3 mJy and 3.4 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a singal-to-noise ratio of about 10 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 3.4 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 2.5 beams. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 4.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 4.2 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 4.
We set a LAS size of 5.4 arcsec, correponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.
All basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: n3256
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For NGC 3256, the observed CO(2-1) flux is 24.5 Jy (Aalto et al. 1995). Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 61 mJy and 20 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a singal-to-noise ratio of about 12 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 4 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 10 beams. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 5.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 10 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 2.
For NGC 3256, the H2CO line is expected to be mainly from the central compact region of about 5-6 arcsec, corresponding to about 1kpc in physical extent. The extended line emission exists over 15 arcsec or more. Thus, we set the LAS size to be 15 arcsec to request an ACA observation.
All basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: n1614
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For NGC 1614, Tmb(CO 3-2)=303 mK, and 1 K=35.1 Jy for HHT 10m telescope (Mao et al. 2010), the expected CO(2-1) flux is 10.6 Jy if Tmb(CO 3-2)/Tmb(CO 2-1)=1. Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 26.6 mJy and 8.9 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a singal-to-noise ratio of about 15 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 5 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 3.5 beams. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 6.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 2.9 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 1.6.
We set a LAS size of 6.4 arcsec, correponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.
All basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: n7469
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For NGC 7469, Tmb(CO 3-2)=133 mK, and 1 K=35.1 Jy for HHT 10m telescope (Mao et al. 2010), the expected CO(2-1) flux is 4.7 Jy if Tmb(CO 3-2)/Tmb(CO 2-1)=1. Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 11.7 mJy and 3.9 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a singal-to-noise ratio of about 9 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 3 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 3.3 beams. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 4.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 2.7 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 2.
We set a LAS size of 6.2 arcsec, correponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.
All basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For IRAS 13120-5453, the observed CO(2-1) flux by the APEX telescope is 3.0 Jy (Ao et al. in preparation), Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 7.6 mJy and 2.5 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a singal-to-noise ratio of about 15 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 5 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission comes from a region of 1~kpc.
We set a LAS size of 3.2 arcsec, correponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.
All basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Ultraluminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) are characterized by high far infrared luminosities from active galactic nuclei and extreme starbursts that are very compact with the bulk of their molecular gas in a very dense phase. Recent evidence points to their very elevated cosmic-ray (CR) energy densities and/or extreme turbulence rather than far-UV/optical radiation fields as those warming their massive dense gas reservoirs. If this is indeed the case it will be of large consequences for all SF events with high star formation rate (SFR) densities taking place in the local or distant Universe, as it will likely alter the initial conditions of star formation and perhaps even the stellar initial mass function (IMF) in a systematic fashion. Formaldehyde (H2CO) is an excellent tracer of molecular gas to study gas excitation as demonstrated in the Galactic studies. We therefore propose to observe the transition lines of H2CO at 218 GHz towards a sample of (U)LIRGs to determine the gas kinetic temperature and to study the heating mechanism for molecular gas in (U)LIRGs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
